Award.AwardTitle: NSF INCLUDES Planning Grant: JEDI Alliance: Justice, Equity, Diversity, and Inclusion in the Geo-and Environmental Sciences

Division.LongName: Div. of Equity for Excellence in STEM

Award.AbstractNarration:
JEDI Alliance: Justice, Equity, Diversity, and Inclusion in the Geo- and Environmental Sciences


This NSF INCLUDES planning grant is funded by NSF Inclusion across the Nation of Communities of Learners of Underrepresented Discoverers in Engineering and Science (NSF INCLUDES), a comprehensive national initiative to enhance U.S. leadership in discoveries and innovations by focusing on diversity, inclusion, and broadening participation in STEM at scale.

The goal of our planning grant is to harness the collaborative potential of the GOLD community so that we can understand what each of the five GOLD projects has learned regarding faculty leadership development for justice, equity, diversity, and inclusion. We also want to combine these strategies into a national alliance focused specifically on justice, equity, diversity, and inclusion in the geo- and environmental sciences. Given these goals, four overarching questions will guide our inquiry:
1. How do the successes and challenges of each of the five GOLD projects broadly inform the process of developing leadership for broadening participation?
2. How can the component pieces from GEO GOLD be woven into a comprehensive model for leadership for broadening participation? How is impact measured across the diverse projects?
3. How does the GOLD learning community effectively transform itself into a collective impact community?
4. What form of a backbone organization best serves the goals and aspirations of the JEDI Alliance?

Planning efforts will lead to the creation of a comprehensive alliance proposal that builds on the groundwork of the five GOLD projects and creates a national alliance to influence a culture of change within the geo- and environmental sciences that promotes justice, equity, diversity, and inclusion (JEDI). The shared vision of our five GOLD projects is to develop the capacity of leadership teams within the field to identify and redress organizational practices that impede broadening participation efforts in the GES. Although we focus on the geosciences, our efforts will be applicable to disciplines in which there is significant fieldwork involved and working in remote research locations. Our planning efforts will also result in identifying a robust backbone organization that will allow us to have true collective impact through coordinated communication, data collection, and collective decision-making.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In 2016, the NSF launched Geoscience Opportunities for Leadership Development (GOLD), a new program to build the geoscience community’s leadership capacity for creating a more just, equitable, diverse, and inclusive field. The GOLD Ideas Lab convened 30 scholars from a wide range of fields, including geosciences and social sciences. Five funded pilot projects emerged from this Ideas Lab. All these projects focused on leadership development for university faculty and administrators. During our planning grant, we convened this diverse group of geoscientists and social scientists from the five funded projects that emerged from the Ideas Lab to explore the possibility of combining our groups into a nationwide Alliance dedicated to developing leaders who can create a more just, equitable, diverse, and inclusive geosciences discipline. We also interviewed members from existing Alliances to better understand the variety of ways that Backbone organizations can function within an Alliance. In consultation with a planning group (Kardia Group), we worked to produce and submit an Alliance proposal.

Through this process of data collection, discussion, and writing a proposal, we learned that the frameworks that guided each of our five pilot projects were too disparate and incompatible to be fit together into a cohesive plan for an Alliance. By collecting evaluation data from each of the five pilot projects, we learned that each pilot project pursued different aims—aims that were different enough that it was difficult to resolve tensions in theoretical frameworks, methodological approaches, and plans of action. Thus, the five pilot project groups decided to pursue different aims seperately. 

Despite these tensions, the lead PI was able to assemble another diverse team of geoscientists and social scientists to write a proposal for a Collaborative Change Consortium. The PI collaborated closely with Dr. Jerlando Jackson and his Organizational Disparities Laboratory. By working with the American Geophysical Union’s Bridge Program, which identifies geoscience departments that are ready to undertake larger systemic change, the team began forming a close Consortium of geoscience organizations in the Lower Chesapeake Bay Watershed region. The PI pulled together leaders from William & Mary’s Virginia Institute of Marine Science, Virginia Tech’s Geoscience Department, University of Maryland Center for Environmental Science, and the Geological Society of America to coalesce around a common vision of “making the invisible visible.” By bringing in an improvement science expert who focuses specifically on a justice-centered networked improvement community, we were able to submit a proposal for a Collaborative Change Consortium to NSF’s INCLUDES program on October 22, 2024.

This Consortium, if funded, will pursue the following common aim, which is shared by all members of the consortium: In five years, we will change the structure and composition of geoscience departments’ organizational networks so that women and Black, Indigenous, People of Color (BIPOC) geoscientists are more directly embedded into the inner workings of their organization. Because our Consortium is a research project at heart, by forming a networked improvement community, we will be able to use an iterative and systematic process to identify a problem of practice (i.e., exclusion of women and BIPOC geoscientists from the decision-making spaces of geoscience organizations) and collectively testing and gathering data on the effectiveness of place-based interventions that target that problem of practice. Doing so can provide a roadmap for others attempting to achieve similar outcomes in other STEM fields.
